bibl.title: Despatch from J.M. Preston to William H. Seward, June 23, 1865
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
Dear Sir:
The vacancy in this Cuncl. Agency caused by the resignation of the May estof. which I mentioned in despatch No. 2, gives me an opportunity here in the United States without infringing the might of anyone, of saying a few words on the U.S. commerce with this port and the suiall need there is for a cosular officer.
The trade has been gradually decreasing for a number of years. For the last three years, on a average three vessels about 600 tons in all a year have come this way from the bright of Benin, to land a few passengers and a little freight and to buy a few thoudand billets of Borovod can article. I believe, not dutiable, and of which a few congors would glut the market to complete their cargoes of Coffee, Camwood, Palm-oil or bought along the coast from Monrovia to Feruaudo PO.
There is no prospect of the prade reviving The Ivory trade is pushed to its which extend . It is in the hands of the English, who can produce the Articles narters for is cheaper more inferior in quality than the American Can.
The India-rubber id being rapidly exhausted Barewood is still plenty; but the French authorities here prevent all vessels from going up the river to trade + thus getting mean the Barwood, and even small boats must procure carry the French flag. This causes delay and increases the price.
American vessels of late, for the sale of despatch, but of the English factories have.
Thus trade does not require the presence of a Condul Rev.
The officer at Gaboon san viot-ruour* about cargies, taken aboard at ports North of this, so as to forward frauds on the revenue*. Besides the greater number of vessels return to the States from ports North of this, at which here has not the opportunity of certifying even to the best of his knowledge to the cargos shipped.
The number of American Citizen residents here has also decreased. Their relations with the authorities have been for the last fifteen years of the most friendly character, and are likely so to remain on their part there had never been a desire for a consular officer at Gaboon. There are a few Americans at lemisco*, but they are under Spanish rule. They may be intefered with; but they could not be much assisted by a consul in a French port, if they are.
Should the United State again send a Aquaron to the West Coast of Africa to corperate with England in supporting the Slave trade, a consul at Gaboon would be of very little use. For several degrees North+ South of this part there is no foreign slave trade, except what is carried on in small schomers about from the Porteguese islands of Prince amd St.Lenard. The slave trade squadrum route have no businep in a french port, where the trade is prohibited.
Fernando Po, as being already a depot for coals, and the Southern terminal of the line of Mail Steamer, and also mean the parts in the Bight of Benin, where the trade is carried on, would become a endevours for our vessel.
In time I do not see what American interest can be advances by the U.S. Comml. Agency. at Gaboon; nor what interest would be in any way prejudices by its disconinuance.
I have done only what I consider my duty to my Country in communicatiing the above of understanding these representations you wish to continue it, I an ready to welcome and assist you appointed as far as I can; or I should feel myself honored in subserving the interests of the United States here, and would if appointed Commercial Agent discharge the duties of the office to the best of my ability. I am free to confess that I desire to urge why it should be conferred upon me rather than another.
I have the honor, to be, you obedient Servant, J.M.Preston.
